Header.title: Revolutionizing the Africa of Tomorrow
Header.paragraph: Step into space where innovation is at the center of what we do.

About.paragraph1: The YAIS is designed to move beyond the standard discussion of Africa’s challenges and instead focus on creating actionable solutions. The conference emphasizes innovative thinking as an important avenue for change. At the YAIS, young, bright minds and African field experts will convene to deconstruct issues and produce resolutions across various African industries.
About.paragraph2: The YAIS format centers around seminar workshops, called “Innovation Labs”, on various topic areas including Finance, Technology, Education, Digital Content Creation, and more. Experts will introduce their industries to their respective Labs, explain some of the challenges they face in their profession, and present a case study from their work that they would like to solve with participants. Participants will then work together through the case study to pinpoint the root causes, identify project goals, and draft approach and implementation strategies.
About.paragraph3: The end goal is for our experts to take the solutions back to their businesses, organizations, and communities and set them in action. Moreover, we hope that the work in the Labs will provide all participants with the foundation to turn their innovative ideas about African development into realities after the conference.

Sponsors.name: The MacMillan Center Council on African Studies
Yale College Faculty of Arts & Sciences
David Geffen School of Drama at Yale University

Team.name: Abigail Ndikum
Team.description: Abigail “Abi” Ndikum is the Executive Director for the inaugural Yale Africa Innovation Symposium. She is a junior at Berkeley College and a double major in Global Affairs and African Studies. Although she was born and raised in the United States, Abi’s family originally comes from Bamenda, Cameroon. Before YAIS, Abigail has also served as the Co-Chair of the Kuwa Women’s Foundation’s Young Leaders Forum; the International Relations Officer for Mother’s Heritage International, and the Director General of Operations for the inaugural 2022 Yale Model African Union conference that took place from May 13 - May 15 in Kigali, Rwanda. She currently works as the Outreach Lead for the youth-led movement Justice For Cameroon. Aside from work, she enjoys cooking, dancing, and spending time with her family in Cameroon. Abi is passionate about creating spaces for people to network, learn, and grow as individuals to become future change-makers. Please feel free to reach out to her at director@yaleafricainnovation.org.

Team.name: Amaris Hester
Team.description: Amaris is a senior in Trumbull College majoring in economics. She is from Ellicott City, MD. Prior to working on the Yale Africa Innovation Symposium, she was the Director of Development for the Yale Debate Association and will lead the upcoming Yale IV tournament in October. She also sings in the Yale Camerata. In her free time, Amaris loves knitting, baking, and listening to music.

Team.name: Ijeamaka Achebe
Team.description: Ijeamaka “Ije” Achebe is a sophomore in Pierson College majoring in the History of Science, Medicine, and Public Health with aspirations of becoming a physician-scientist. While born and raised in the United States, her family comes from Anambra state in Nigeria and she hopes to utilize the skills she learns while studying here to improve healthcare outcomes for Black mothers in the US and in Africa. Before YAIS, she served as the social media chair for Dzana, Yale’s premier Afrofusion dance team; a member of the finance and sponsorships committee for the Black Solidarity Conference, and  a community health educator, through which she taught health classes to students in New Haven. Ije also spent her senior year leading a discussion series that she created to talk about core cultural identifiers such as race, gender and sexuality, and ability. When she’s not dancing, she can also be found hanging out with friends and family or working in Dr. Sunil Parikh’s lab on malaria research. Next year she will be the president of Dzana, on the steering committee of community health educators, and leading the finance and sponsorship team for the Black Solidarity conference. She cannot wait to use her experience to further the mission of YAIS. Feel free to reach out to Ije through outreach@yaleafricainnovation.org  or ijeamaka.achebe@yale.edu

Team.name: Mariama Sow
Team.description: Mariama Sow, the Co-Officer of Operations for the Yale Africa Innovation Symposium, is a first-generation Guienan Muslim woman born and raised in New York City. Looking into political and social activism, she currently takes classes that examines the divergence of blackness, wondering if it transcends an ocean. Traversing Black archives from Africa to the Americas, she takes classes that expose the juxtaposition of white intrusion as a detrimental contender to the political and socio-economic spheres of both countries. Her past year at Yale, she has joined an African Dance Team and Step Dance Team, as well as volunteered with the Yale Undergraduate Prison Program. Currently working on Capitol Hill and with a non-profit organization, her passion for civil rights and collective Black liberation in communities intensifies. In her free time, she is a Co-Founder of a podcast called Beacon of Eachother that focuses on the intersectionality of students as they navigate their POC experience as adults and take up space at a white institution like Yale. As a rising sophomore she intends to take up more space, bringing not just Black and Brown joy onto the campus, but innovative solutions for Black people everywhere—starting with YAIS. You can reach her at mariama.sow@yale.edu.

Team.name: Grace Dossou
Team.description: Grace Dossou is a sophomore in Pauli Murray College majoring in History of Science, Medicine, and Public Health. She is originally from Cotonou Benin and resides in Lillington, North Carolina. Within her first year she joined the cheer team and worked as a research assistant in the Hoffman Lab, which focuses on neurodevelopmental disorders using zebrafish. During her free time she enjoys cooking food that reminds her of home and exploring different cities and states with friends. Grace hopes to unite her medical research, and gender studies background to improve the equity in healthcare of black women and other women of color.

Team.name: Arlene Tetteh-Lartey
Team.description: Arlene Tetteh-Lartey is a sophomore at Timothy Dwight College majoring in Neuroscience.  She was born and raised in Lowell, Massachusetts, and her family comes from Ghana and Zimbabwe. During her first year, she served as Business Manager for Danceworks, served as a vice-chair for Yale Model United Nations, and joined the Cardin Lab, studying neuroscience and psychology. Arlene enjoys going on walks with friends, listening to music, and decorating. Later on, she hopes to do research on neurological disorders and how it affects various marginalized groups.

Team.name: Georgette Uweranyiraneza
Team.description: Georgette Uwera Nyiraneza is a sophomore at Yale University in Timothy Dwight College, where she is a prospective Sociology and Data Science double major. She was born and raised in Rwanda, and her experiences with education in her country and curiosities about African history and society inspired her interests in social science and humanities research. Georgette is currently involved with education policy, working under the Rwandan Ministry of Education as an intern, and she hopes to contribute to policy research and academic research on the continent to expand the resources accessible to Africans to learn about their continent. Georgette serves as a board member for the Yale Black Women’s Coalition, and she is also a member of the Yale International Relations Association. In her free time, Georgette enjoys reading, writing, and singing in the Yale Gospel Choir. You can reach her at outreach@yaleafricainnovation.org or georgette.uweranyiraneza@yale.edu

Team.name: Afia Sarpong Frimpong
Team.description: Afia Sarpong Frimpong is a co-officer of outreach for YAIS and a 2022 graduate of Yale College. She majored in biomedical engineering with a concentration in tissue engineering and is currently working as an American Heart Association summer fellow at the Yale School of Medicine. Afia was born and raised in Accra, Ghana. During her time at Yale, Afia participated in a variety of activities including the Yale Gospel Choir, where she served as the business secretary (2019/2020) and Vice- President (2021/2022), and was involved in planning and executing concerts for students and public audiences. She was also a Student Organizations Consultant (2021/2022) where she acted as a liaison between the Yale College Dean's Office and student groups, and led workshops to promote growth of these organizations. Outside of the Yale community, Afia is a volunteer tutor for middle school and high school students to promote their interest in STEM courses. She loves to read novels in her free time and is passionate about healthcare and making positive impacts in society and on those around her. Feel free to reach out to Afia at outreach@yaleafricainnovation.org.
